Contour methods for long-range Ising models: weakening nearest-neighbor interactions and adding decaying fields.
Rodrigo Bissacot1, Eric O. Endo1,2, Aernout C. D. van Enter2, Bruno Kimura3 and Wioletta M. Ruszel3 1Institute of Mathematics and Statistics (IME-USP), University of São Paulo, Brazil 2Johann Bernoulli Institute, University of Groningen, the Netherlands 3Delft Institute for Applied Mathematics, Technical University Delft, the Netherlands emails: rodrigo.bissacot@gmail.com; eric@ime.usp.br; avanenter@gmail.com; bruno.hfkimura@gmail.com; w.m.ruszel@tudelft.nl


Abstract. We consider ferromagnetic long-range Ising models which display phase transitions. They are one-dimensional Ising ferromagnets, in which the interaction is given by Jx,y=J​(|x−y|)≡1|x−y|2−αsubscript𝐽𝑥𝑦𝐽𝑥𝑦1superscript𝑥𝑦2𝛼J_{x,y}=J(|x-y|)\equiv\frac{1}{|x-y|^{2-\alpha}} with α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), in particular, J​(1)=1𝐽11J(1)=1. For this class of models one way in which one can prove the phase transition is via a kind of Peierls contour argument, using the adaptation of the Fröhlich-Spencer contours for α≠0𝛼0\alpha\neq 0, proposed by Cassandro, Ferrari, Merola and Presutti. As proved by Fröhlich and Spencer for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 and conjectured by Cassandro et al for the region they could treat, α∈(0,α+)𝛼0subscript𝛼\alpha\in(0,\alpha_{+}) for α+=log⁡(3)/log⁡(2)−1subscript𝛼321\alpha_{+}=\log(3)/\log(2)-1, although in the literature dealing with contour methods for these models it is generally assumed that J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1, we will show that this condition can be removed in the contour analysis. In addition, combining our theorem with a recent result of Littin and Picco we prove the persistence of the contour proof of the phase transition for any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1). Moreover, we show that when we add a magnetic field decaying to zero, given by hx=h∗⋅(1+|x|)−γsubscriptℎ𝑥⋅subscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma} and γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α∗}𝛾1𝛼1superscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\} where α∗≈0.2714superscript𝛼0.2714\alpha^{*}\approx 0.2714, the transition still persists.

1. Introduction

The rigorous study of phase transitions for one-dimensional Ising models with long-range slowly decaying interactions (Dyson models) is a classical subject in one-dimensional statistical mechanics. One of the earliest highlights, almost 50 years ago, was Dyson’s proof of a phase transition [16, 17, 18], proving a conjecture due to Kac and Thompson [24]. Long-range Ising models with slow polynomial decay, as well as the somewhat related hierarchical models, have been called “Dyson models” in the literature. We will mostly call our polynomially decaying models “long-range Ising models” but sometimes refer to them as “Dyson models”.

The formal Hamiltonian of these models is given by:

(1.1) H​(σ)=−∑x≠yJx,y​σx​σy−∑xhx​σx𝐻𝜎subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝐽𝑥𝑦subscript𝜎𝑥subscript𝜎𝑦subscript𝑥subscriptℎ𝑥subscript𝜎𝑥H(\sigma)=-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}x\neq y\end{subarray}}J_{x,y}\sigma_{x}\sigma_{y}-\sum_{x}h_{x}\sigma_{x}

Here the sites x,y𝑥𝑦x,y live in ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}, the σxsubscript𝜎𝑥\sigma_{x} are Ising spins. More precise definitions are given in the next section. We first mention what is known for the zero-field case, i.e. when hx=0subscriptℎ𝑥0h_{x}=0 for all x𝑥x.

We consider ferromagnetic interactions Jx,y≥0subscript𝐽𝑥𝑦0J_{x,y}\geq 0 given by Jx,y=|x−y|−2+αsubscript𝐽𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥𝑦2𝛼J_{x,y}=|x-y|^{-2+\alpha} with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1. It is well known that for α<0𝛼0\alpha<0 there is no phase transition, and Dyson showed in [16] via comparison with a hierarchical model, that, for α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1), we have a phase transition at low temperature.

Afterwards different proofs were invented to show the transition. One of them used Reflection Positivity [19]. The method of infrared bounds offers an alternative to obtaining bounds on contour probabilities. In fact, the authors of [19] remark that they can cover a general class of long-range one-dimensional pair interactions, including the ones treated in [16].

Shortly after, Fröhlich and Spencer [20] showed the existence of a phase transition for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. The proof of these authors was done by a contour argument; they invented a notion of one-dimensional contours on ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} in order to prove the phase transition. Their strategy more or less followed the classical Peierls contour argument used for the standard nearest-neighbor Ising model, but with a substantially more sophisticated definition of contours. Phase transitions for larger α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) can then be deduced by Griffiths inequalities for low enough temperature.

Yet another way to derive the transition was a comparison with independent long-range percolation via Fortuin inequalities and Griffiths inequalities for the α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 case, as discussed in [1]. In that paper it was also shown that the transition for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 is a hybrid one, in the sense that the magnetisation is discontinuous and at the same time the energy is continuous as a function of temperature (Thouless effect). Moreover, for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 it is known that there is a temperature interval below the transition temperature where the system is critical, in the sense that the covariance is nonsummable, and at the same time the system is magnetized.

Cassandro et al. in [10] rigorously formalized the contour argument of [20] in the parameter regime 0≤α<α+0𝛼subscript𝛼0\leq\alpha<\alpha_{+}, where α+:=log⁡3/log⁡2−1≈0.5849assignsubscript𝛼3210.5849\alpha_{+}:=\log 3/\log 2-1\approx 0.5849. The construction allows a more precise description of various properties of the model. It has been used in various follow-up papers [8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 27, 29]. We should emphasize that, although the use of contour arguments may look somewhat unwieldy in comparison with other approaches, it is much more robust. Indeed it has been used to analyze Dyson models in random [13, 14] and periodic fields [25], for interface behaviour and phase separation [11, 12], for entropic repulsion [8], and here for the model in decaying magnetic fields, all problems where alternative methods appear to break down.

See also [23] for another, somewhat related approach.

However, the adaptation proposed by Cassandro et al. in [10] needed the following technical assumptions: (A1): α∈[0,α+)𝛼0superscript𝛼\alpha\in[0,\alpha^{+}) and (A2): J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1.

Even the case of α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, previously obtained by Fröhlich and Spencer, needs J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1 in the adaptation proposed by them. The intuition behind the condition is more or less clear; it makes the model closer to a nearest-neighbor interaction model where, in principle, contour arguments might work more easily. Despite the condition being rather artificial and proof-generated, the constraint asking for J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1 is present in many later papers about Dyson models and the proof presented in [10] depends strongly on this hypothesis.

As regards the restriction on α𝛼\alpha, Littin in his thesis [27], and then Littin and Picco [29], showed that, using quasi-additive properties of the Hamiltonian of the corresponding contour model and applying the results from [10], one can modify the contour argument so that it implies the phase transition for all α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1). Due to the fact that the authors in [29] use energetic lower bounds from [10] which assume large nearest-neighbour interaction J​(1)𝐽1J(1), they still use assumption (A2) in their arguments.

Our motivation for the present work is two-fold: first we want to present an argument to remove assumption (A2) for the zero-field case and secondly we want to show persistence of a phase transition for one-dimensional long-range models in the presence of external fields decaying to zero at infinity with a power γ𝛾\gamma, in particular, for fields given by hx=h∗​(1+|x|)−γsubscriptℎ𝑥subscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾h_{x}=h_{*}(1+|x|)^{-\gamma} and 1−α<γ1𝛼𝛾1-\alpha<\gamma. More precisely, our results combined with existing results imply that there is a trade-off between the restricting the parameter range of γ𝛾\gamma to γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α∗}𝛾1𝛼1superscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\} and general J​(1)𝐽1J(1) and assuming J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1 and choosing γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α+}𝛾1𝛼1subscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha_{+}\} where α+>α∗subscript𝛼superscript𝛼\alpha_{+}>\alpha^{*} will be specified later. Note that our results apply to the latter case as well.

Before describing the rest of the paper, we will discuss briefly the context of these results with respect to the hypotheses and technicalities of the proof. Let us mention that a short announcement of some of our results, but without rigorous proofs, is contained in [7].

Considering the first result in the zero-field case, although proofs for the existence of a phase transition were known, our estimates allow firstly to drop the (A2) assumption, and then, by using monotonicity of the Hamiltonian with respect to α𝛼\alpha, we are also able to remove the first assumption (A1).

As regarding the decaying-field case we know that phase transitions for non-zero uniform fields are forbidden due to the Lee-Yang circle theorem [26].

The heuristics behind the inequality 1−α<γ1𝛼𝛾1-\alpha<\gamma can be obtained as follows. We observe that the contribution of the interaction of a finite interval ΛΛ\Lambda with its complement is of order O​(|Λ|α)𝑂superscriptΛ𝛼O(|\Lambda|^{\alpha}), whereas the contribution from the external field is of order O​(|Λ|1−γ)𝑂superscriptΛ1𝛾O(|\Lambda|^{1-\gamma}).

We now compare the exponents. If the interaction energy dominates the field energy for large ΛΛ\Lambda, a contour argument has a chance of working. This intuition is also what is underlying Imry-Ma arguments for analyzing the stability of phase transitions in the presence of random fields. It has been confirmed for decaying fields in higher-dimensional nearest-neighbour models, see below.

It can also be applied to a decaying field the strength of which decays with power γ𝛾\gamma but which has random signs. In this case the field energy behaves like O​(|Λ|12−γ)𝑂superscriptΛ12𝛾O(|\Lambda|^{\frac{1}{2}-\gamma}). This case has also been considered before by J. Littin (private communication) [28]. We note that the case γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 reduces to the known Imry-Ma analysis as presented in [13, 14].

Note that the analogous question of the persistence of phase transitions in decaying fields already was studied before in some short-range models, see [5, 4, 6, 15].

The paper is organized as follows. In the section 2 we introduce the definition of the model and some notation. The following section 3 presents the main results. Section 4 introduces the construction of the contours and section 5 contains the proofs of the main theorems including the Peierls argument. Finally section 6 concludes with a summary and discussion about open questions.

3. Main Results

In this section we present our main results. The first result concerns the phase transition for the Dyson model for any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1) and removing the J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1 assumption and the second result concerns the persistence of the phase transition under decaying external fields.

Theorem 1.

Let us consider an Ising model on ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} with Hamiltonian given by (2.1) for α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), J​(1)=1𝐽11J(1)=1 and hx≡0subscriptℎ𝑥0h_{x}\equiv 0 for all x∈ℤ𝑥ℤx\in\mathbb{Z}. Then there exists βc>0subscript𝛽𝑐0\beta_{c}>0 such that for all β>βc𝛽subscript𝛽𝑐\beta>\beta_{c} we have a convergent low-temperature expansion which implies that |𝒢​(0,β)|>1𝒢0𝛽1|\mathcal{G}(0,\beta)|>1.

Theorem 2.

Let α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} be such that ∑k=1∞k−2+α∗=2superscriptsubscript𝑘1superscript𝑘2superscript𝛼2\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}k^{-2+\alpha^{*}}=2. Consider an Ising model on ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} with Hamiltonian given by (2.1) such that h¯=(hx)x∈ℤ¯ℎsubscriptsubscriptℎ𝑥𝑥ℤ\overline{h}=(h_{x})_{x\in\mathbb{Z}} are defined by hx=h∗⋅(1+|x|)−γsubscriptℎ𝑥⋅subscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma}. We assume either

  • •

    α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1), J​(1)=1𝐽11J(1)=1, h∗∈ℝsubscriptℎℝh_{*}\in\mathbb{R} and γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α∗}𝛾1𝛼1superscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\}, or

  • •

    α∈[0,α∗)𝛼0superscript𝛼\alpha\in[0,\alpha^{*}), J​(1)=1𝐽11J(1)=1, γ=1−α𝛾1𝛼\gamma=1-\alpha and h∗subscriptℎh_{*} small enough.

Then there exists βc>0subscript𝛽𝑐0\beta_{c}>0 such that for all β>βc𝛽subscript𝛽𝑐\beta>\beta_{c} we have that |𝒢​(h¯,β)|>1𝒢¯ℎ𝛽1|\mathcal{G}(\overline{h},\beta)|>1.

Remark: In the case of α=0𝛼0\alpha=0, although it is the most complicated in general (the proof of the phase transition took more time [20], there is a mixed first-order second-order transition -the Thouless effect, as proven in [1], see also [31]- and there exists an intermediate phase, magnetised but with nonsummable covariance [22] in some temperature interval below the transition temperature), for our problem the situation becomes actually somewhat simpler. Indeed, in that case the condition γ>1𝛾1\gamma>1 implies that the field energy is uniformly bounded, and thus the phase transition persists, whenever it occurs, due to the arguments of [5]. This applies at all temperatures where there is a phase transition, including the intermediate phase, and is not dependent on the applicability of contour arguments. However, for the critical value γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 and the field strength weak enough, our proof does apply only at very low temperatures.

4. Triangles and contours

The proof will consist of a Peierls type argument in one dimension. We start by defining the notion of triangles which was first described in [20] for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 and adapted for 0≤α<10𝛼10\leq\alpha<1 in [10].

Let N≥1𝑁1N\geq 1, and consider an interval Λ=ΛN=[−N,N]ΛsubscriptΛ𝑁𝑁𝑁\Lambda=\Lambda_{N}=[-N,N]. Define the dual lattice Λ∗=Λ+12superscriptΛΛ12\Lambda^{*}=\Lambda+\frac{1}{2} as the set ΛΛ\Lambda shifted by 1/2121/2. Given a configuration σ∈{−1,+1}Λ𝜎superscript11Λ\sigma\in\{-1,+1\}^{\Lambda}, let us define configurations of triangles. A spin -flip point is a site i𝑖i in Λ∗superscriptΛ\Lambda^{*} such that σi−12≠σi+12subscript𝜎𝑖12subscript𝜎𝑖12\sigma_{i-\frac{1}{2}}\neq\sigma_{i+\frac{1}{2}}. For each spin-flip point i𝑖i, let us consider the interval [i−1100,i+1100]⊂ℝ𝑖1100𝑖1100ℝ\left[i-\frac{1}{100},i+\frac{1}{100}\right]\subset\mathbb{R} and choose a real number risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} in this interval such that, for every four distinct rilsubscript𝑟subscript𝑖𝑙r_{i_{l}} with l=1,…,4𝑙1…4l=1,\ldots,4, we have |ri1−ri2|≠|ri3−ri4|subscript𝑟subscript𝑖1subscript𝑟subscript𝑖2subscript𝑟subscript𝑖3subscript𝑟subscript𝑖4|r_{i_{1}}-r_{i_{2}}|\neq|r_{i_{3}}-r_{i_{4}}|. The risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} are the bases of the triangles, and the last condition on risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} is to avoid ambiguity in the construction of the triangles below.

For each spin-flip point i𝑖i, we start growing a “∨\lor-line” at risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} where this ∨\lor-line is embedded in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} with angles π/4𝜋4\pi/4 and 3​π/43𝜋43\pi/4. If at some time two ∨\lor-lines starting from different spin-flip points touch, the other two lines starting from those two spin-flip points stop growing and we remove those lines -which did not form a triangle-, and we keep continuing this process. The process can also be seen in the following way: for each risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, we draw a straight vertical line passing through it. Take the smallest distance between these lines, let us call the corresponding risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} and rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j} the spin-flip points of these lines, and draw a isosceles triangle with base angle π/4𝜋4\pi/4. Then, remove the lines associated to risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} and rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j}, and continue the process.

Note that, for any finite interval ΛΛ\Lambda with homogeneous boundary condition, the number of spin flips is even, and so every risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} is a vertex of some triangle. Let us denote by 𝒮Λ+subscript𝒮superscriptΛ\mathcal{S}_{\Lambda^{+}} be the set of configurations with plus boundary condition, i.e., for σ∈𝒮Λ+𝜎subscript𝒮superscriptΛ\sigma\in\mathcal{S}_{\Lambda^{+}} we have σx=+1subscript𝜎𝑥1\sigma_{x}=+1 for every x∉Λ𝑥Λx\notin\Lambda.

Note that it is straightforward that there exists a bijection between spin configurations in 𝒮Λ+subscript𝒮superscriptΛ\mathcal{S}_{\Lambda^{+}} and triangles in 𝒯Λ+subscript𝒯superscriptΛ\mathcal{T}_{\Lambda^{+}}, and also T¯↦Γ¯​(T¯)maps-to¯𝑇¯Γ¯𝑇\underline{T}\mapsto\underline{\Gamma}(\underline{T}) is a bijection, where T¯∈𝒯Λ+¯𝑇subscript𝒯superscriptΛ\underline{T}\in\mathcal{T}_{\Lambda^{+}}. Entropy of Contours

For any kind of Peierls argument [30] where a notion of a contour is used to obtain the phase transition for a model, the entropy of the contours (that is the -logarithm of- the number of contours of a given size) should be controlled. Recently, generating functions were used on this combinatorial problem of counting contours associated to short-range models on regular trees [2] and on ℤd,d≥2superscriptℤ𝑑𝑑2\mathbb{Z}^{d},d\geq 2, see [3]. For trees the method allows us to find the exact number of contours of a fixed size and for ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d} these are the best estimates until now.

The entropy of contours introduced in [10] was inspired by [20] and it satisfies the following estimates:

For any real b>0𝑏0b>0 large enough and integer m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1, we have, for α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1),

(4.14) ∑|Γ|=m0∈Γe−b​∑T∈Γ|T|α≤2​m​e−b​mα.subscriptΓ𝑚0Γsuperscript𝑒𝑏subscript𝑇Γsuperscript𝑇𝛼2𝑚superscript𝑒𝑏superscript𝑚𝛼\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}|\Gamma|=m\\ 0\in\Gamma\end{subarray}}e^{-b\sum_{T\in\Gamma}|T|^{\alpha}}\leq 2me^{-bm^{\alpha}}.

In the case α=0𝛼0\alpha=0,

(4.15) ∑|Γ|=m0∈Γe−b​∑T∈Γ(log⁡(|T|)+4)≤2​m​e−b​(log⁡m+4).subscriptΓ𝑚0Γsuperscript𝑒𝑏subscript𝑇Γ𝑇42𝑚superscript𝑒𝑏𝑚4\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}|\Gamma|=m\\ 0\in\Gamma\end{subarray}}e^{-b\sum_{T\in\Gamma}(\log(|T|)+4)}\leq 2me^{-b(\log m+4)}.

The proof is done by induction on m𝑚m and using a graphical representation of contours by trees. This representation requires a process, called the square process, to create the structure of a tree from any contour. The existence of such an algorithm can be found in [10].

Quasi-additive properties of the Hamiltonian

In order to control the energy for the proof of phase transition via contours, Cassandro et al. in [10] showed that there exist Cα>0subscript𝐶𝛼0C_{\alpha}>0 for α∈(0,α+)𝛼0subscript𝛼\alpha\in(0,\alpha_{+}) such that

(4.16) Hα+​(Γ0|Γ¯\{Γ0})≥Cα2​∑T∈Γ0|T|α,superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼conditionalsubscriptΓ0\¯ΓsubscriptΓ0subscript𝐶𝛼2subscript𝑇subscriptΓ0superscript𝑇𝛼H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq\frac{C_{\alpha}}{2}\sum_{T\in\Gamma_{0}}|T|^{\alpha},

and

(4.17) Hα+​(Γ0|Γ¯\{Γ0})≥C02​∑T∈Γ0log⁡(|T|+4),superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼conditionalsubscriptΓ0\¯ΓsubscriptΓ0subscript𝐶02subscript𝑇subscriptΓ0𝑇4H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq\frac{C_{0}}{2}\sum_{T\in\Gamma_{0}}\log(|T|+4),

for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0. The constant Cα=3−21+αα​(1−α)subscript𝐶𝛼3superscript21𝛼𝛼1𝛼C_{\alpha}=\frac{3-2^{1+\alpha}}{\alpha(1-\alpha)} converges to zero when α→α+→𝛼subscript𝛼\alpha\to\alpha_{+}. Those bounds only work when the energy of the nearest neighbors J​(1)𝐽1J(1) is large enough. Littin and Picco [29] showed that there is no possibility to extend those bounds in terms of triangles to any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), constructing a sequence of contours (Γn)n≥1subscriptsubscriptΓ𝑛𝑛1(\Gamma_{n})_{n\geq 1} such that

(4.18) limn→∞Hα+​(Γn)∑T∈Γn|T|α=0subscript→𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼subscriptΓ𝑛subscript𝑇subscriptΓ𝑛superscript𝑇𝛼0\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{n})}{\sum_{T\in\Gamma_{n}}|T|^{\alpha}}=0

for 0≤α<α+0𝛼subscript𝛼0\leq\alpha<\alpha_{+}.

Their construction explains, in some sense, the value of the constant α+=log⁡3/log⁡2−1subscript𝛼321\alpha_{+}=\log 3/\log 2-1 which could be considered kind of magical, since the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is exactly log⁡2/log⁡323\log 2/\log 3. In fact, a discrete Cantor set appears in the construction. However, [29] showed the quasi-additive property of the Hamiltonian for any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1), in other words, the following inequality is satisfied,

(4.19) Hα+​(Γ0|Γ¯\{Γ0})≥Kc​(α)​Hα+​[Γ0],superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼conditionalsubscriptΓ0\¯ΓsubscriptΓ0subscript𝐾𝑐𝛼superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼delimited-[]subscriptΓ0H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq K_{c}(\alpha)H_{\alpha}^{+}[\Gamma_{0}],

where Kc​(α)=1−αcα−1−π26​csubscript𝐾𝑐𝛼1𝛼superscript𝑐𝛼1superscript𝜋26𝑐K_{c}(\alpha)=1-\frac{\alpha}{c^{\alpha-1}}-\frac{\pi^{2}}{6c} satisfies 0<Kc​(α)≤120subscript𝐾𝑐𝛼120<K_{c}(\alpha)\leq\frac{1}{2} where c𝑐c is large enough. This property allows the authors to prove the phase transition for any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1) as a corollary from the case when α∈[0,α+)𝛼0subscript𝛼\alpha\in[0,\alpha_{+}). As [29] mentioned, Fröhlich and Spencer [20] already noticed that the Hamiltonian satisfies the quasi-additivity.

5. Proof of the main Theorems

5.1. Proof of Theorem 1

By Lemma A.1 from [10] there is a lower bound for Wαsubscript𝑊𝛼W_{\alpha} which allows one to use the contour argument and prove the phase transition. In fact, they showed that, for any α∈[0,α+)𝛼0subscript𝛼\alpha\in[0,\alpha_{+}) and J​(1)𝐽1J(1) large enough, we have, for every L≥1𝐿1L\geq 1,

(5.1) Wα​(L)≥{ζα​Lα, if ​α∈(0,α+);2​(log⁡L+4), if ​α=0,subscript𝑊𝛼𝐿casessubscript𝜁𝛼superscript𝐿𝛼 if 𝛼0subscript𝛼2𝐿4 if 𝛼0W_{\alpha}(L)\geq\begin{cases}\zeta_{\alpha}L^{\alpha},&\text{ if }\alpha\in(0,\alpha_{+});\\ 2(\log L+4),&\text{ if }\alpha=0,\end{cases}

The proof in [10] uses monotonicity of J​(⋅)𝐽⋅J(\cdot) to replace sums by integrals, and J​(1)𝐽1J(1) should be large if we desire to have this bound for small L𝐿L, this is an essential hypothesis for the argument. The proposition below shows that, at the cost of reducing the interval of α𝛼\alpha, the condition J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1 can be substituted by J​(1)=1𝐽11J(1)=1.

Proposition 1.

Consider 0<α∗<10superscript𝛼10<\alpha^{*}<1 satisfying

(5.2) ∑n=1∞1n2−α∗=2.superscriptsubscript𝑛11superscript𝑛2superscript𝛼2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^{2-\alpha^{*}}}=2.

5.2. Proof of Theorem 2

We first prove the theorem for all α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1) and external fields defined by hx=h∗⋅(1+|x|)−γsubscriptℎ𝑥⋅subscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma} where max⁡{1−α,1−α∗}<γ≤11𝛼1superscript𝛼𝛾1\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\}<\gamma\leq 1. The proof will be a modified version of the Peierls argument presented in the previous section. It is enough to find an appropriate lower bound as in (5.26). Given a positive integer L𝐿L, let us consider the external field h¯L=(hL,x)x∈ℤsubscript¯ℎ𝐿subscriptsubscriptℎ𝐿𝑥𝑥ℤ\bar{h}_{L}=(h_{L,x})_{x\in\mathbb{Z}} defined as

(5.27) hL,x={0if |x|<L,h∗(1+|x|)γotherwise.subscriptℎ𝐿𝑥cases0if |x|<Lsuperscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾otherwiseh_{L,x}=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $|x|<L$},\\ \frac{h^{*}}{(1+|x|)^{\gamma}}&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases}

We can consider this modified field without loss of generality because any local perturbation does not change the fact that the model undergoes a phase transition. In fact, any finite-energy perturbation does not destroy the presence (or the absence) of a phase transition. This is the reason that we do not need to consider γ>1𝛾1\gamma>1 since in that case the external field is summable, see [21] for more details.

Let Γ∈Γ¯Γ¯Γ\Gamma\in\underline{\Gamma} be a contour. Note that

(5.28) |𝟙{σx​(Γ¯)=−1}−𝟙{σx​(Γ¯∖Γ)=−1}|≤𝟙{x∈ℤ∩Γ}.subscript1subscript𝜎𝑥¯Γ1subscript1subscript𝜎𝑥¯ΓΓ1subscript1𝑥ℤΓ|\mathbbm{1}_{\{\sigma_{x}(\underline{\Gamma})=-1\}}-\mathbbm{1}_{\{\sigma_{x}(\underline{\Gamma}\setminus\Gamma)=-1\}}|\leq\mathbbm{1}_{\{x\in\mathbb{Z}\cap\Gamma\}}.

Again by inequality (4.19),

Hh¯L,α+​[Γ¯]−Hh¯L,α+​[Γ¯∖Γ]subscriptsuperscript𝐻subscript¯ℎ𝐿𝛼delimited-[]¯Γsubscriptsuperscript𝐻subscript¯ℎ𝐿𝛼delimited-[]¯ΓΓ\displaystyle H^{+}_{\bar{h}_{L},\alpha}[\underline{\Gamma}]-H^{+}_{\bar{h}_{L},\alpha}[\underline{\Gamma}\setminus\Gamma] =Hα+​[Γ¯]−Hα+​[Γ¯∖Γ]+∑x∈ℤhL,x⋅(𝟙{σx​(Γ¯)=−1}−𝟙{σx​(Γ¯∖Γ)=−1})absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼delimited-[]¯Γsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼delimited-[]¯ΓΓsubscript𝑥ℤ⋅subscriptℎ𝐿𝑥subscript1subscript𝜎𝑥¯Γ1subscript1subscript𝜎𝑥¯ΓΓ1\displaystyle=H_{\alpha}^{+}[\underline{\Gamma}]-H_{\alpha}^{+}[\underline{\Gamma}\setminus\Gamma]+\sum_{x\in\mathbb{Z}}h_{L,x}\cdot\left(\mathbbm{1}_{\{\sigma_{x}(\underline{\Gamma})=-1\}}-\mathbbm{1}_{\{\sigma_{x}(\underline{\Gamma}\setminus\Gamma)=-1\}}\right)
≥Kc​(α)​Hα+​[Γ]−∑T∈Γ∑x∈T∩ℤ|hL,x|.absentsubscript𝐾𝑐𝛼superscriptsubscript𝐻𝛼delimited-[]Γsubscript𝑇Γsubscript𝑥𝑇ℤsubscriptℎ𝐿𝑥\displaystyle\geq K_{c}(\alpha)H_{\alpha}^{+}[\Gamma]-\sum_{T\in\Gamma}\sum_{x\in T\cap\mathbb{Z}}|h_{L,x}|.

We can find the following upper bound for the contribution of the external fields, there is C>0𝐶0C>0 such that

(5.29) ∑T∈Γ∑x∈T∩ℤ|hL,x|≤C​|h∗|1−γ​L−p​∥Γ∥1−γ.subscript𝑇Γsubscript𝑥𝑇ℤsubscriptℎ𝐿𝑥𝐶subscriptℎ1𝛾superscript𝐿𝑝subscriptdelimited-∥∥Γ1𝛾\displaystyle\sum_{T\in\Gamma}\sum_{x\in T\cap\mathbb{Z}}|h_{L,x}|\leq\frac{C|h_{*}|}{1-\gamma}L^{-p}\lVert\Gamma\rVert_{1-\gamma}.

for p=γ+α−1>0𝑝𝛾𝛼10p=\gamma+\alpha-1>0.

Since the Hamiltonian Hα+subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝛼H^{+}_{\alpha} is decreasing in α𝛼\alpha, choose α′∈(0,α∗)superscript𝛼′0superscript𝛼\alpha^{\prime}\in(0,\alpha^{*}) with α′≤αsuperscript𝛼′𝛼\alpha^{\prime}\leq\alpha such that 1−γ<α′1𝛾superscript𝛼′1-\gamma<\alpha^{\prime}. Then, by Proposition 1,

(5.30) Hα′+​[Γ]≥ζα′​∥Γ∥α′.superscriptsubscript𝐻superscript𝛼′delimited-[]Γsubscript𝜁superscript𝛼′subscriptdelimited-∥∥Γsuperscript𝛼′H_{\alpha^{\prime}}^{+}[\Gamma]\geq\zeta_{\alpha^{\prime}}\lVert\Gamma\rVert_{\alpha^{\prime}}.

Therefore,

(5.31) Hh¯L,α+​[Γ¯]−Hh¯L,α+​[Γ¯∖Γ]≥Kc​(α)​ζα′​∥Γ∥α′−C​|h∗|1−γ​L−p​∥Γ∥α′.subscriptsuperscript𝐻subscript¯ℎ𝐿𝛼delimited-[]¯Γsubscriptsuperscript𝐻subscript¯ℎ𝐿𝛼delimited-[]¯ΓΓsubscript𝐾𝑐𝛼subscript𝜁superscript𝛼′subscriptdelimited-∥∥Γsuperscript𝛼′𝐶subscriptℎ1𝛾superscript𝐿𝑝subscriptdelimited-∥∥Γsuperscript𝛼′\begin{split}H^{+}_{\bar{h}_{L},\alpha}[\underline{\Gamma}]-H^{+}_{\bar{h}_{L},\alpha}[\underline{\Gamma}\setminus\Gamma]&\geq K_{c}(\alpha)\zeta_{\alpha^{\prime}}\lVert\Gamma\rVert_{\alpha^{\prime}}-\frac{C|h_{*}|}{1-\gamma}L^{-p}\lVert\Gamma\rVert_{\alpha^{\prime}}.\end{split}

Choosing L𝐿L large enough such that Kc​(α)​ζα′−C​|h∗|1−γ​L−p>0subscript𝐾𝑐𝛼subscript𝜁superscript𝛼′𝐶subscriptℎ1𝛾superscript𝐿𝑝0K_{c}(\alpha)\zeta_{\alpha^{\prime}}-\frac{C|h_{*}|}{1-\gamma}L^{-p}>0 concludes the proof of the lower bound.

Critical case. For the case when α∈(0,α∗)𝛼0superscript𝛼\alpha\in(0,\alpha^{*}) and γ=1−α𝛾1𝛼\gamma=1-\alpha, we can argue in a similar way. First we take h∗subscriptℎh_{*} small enough the sum (5.29) converges to zero and then, by the same argument above, the model undergoes a phase transition. The argument also holds for α=0𝛼0\alpha=0 and γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, we then have the bound

(5.32) ∑x∈Γ∩ℤhx≤8​|h∗|⋅∑T∈Γlog⁡(|T|)subscript𝑥Γℤsubscriptℎ𝑥⋅8subscriptℎsubscript𝑇Γ𝑇\sum_{x\in\Gamma\cap\mathbb{Z}}h_{x}\leq 8|h_{*}|\cdot\sum_{T\in\Gamma}\log(|T|)

and follow the same argumentation as before.

6. Concluding remarks

In this paper we provided further steps on the way to a better understanding of Dyson models. We were able to remove the artificial hypothesis of J​(1)≫1much-greater-than𝐽11J(1)\gg 1, which is required in most of the literature about contour methods in these models, for the whole range of the exponent of the interaction α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1) in the direct proof of the phase transition via contours. The result suggests that this hypothesis can also be removed in all the subsequent papers based on the contour argument from [10].

Our analysis also allows us to include the case of decaying fields of the type defined by hx=h∗⋅(1+|x|)−γsubscriptℎ𝑥⋅subscriptℎsuperscript1𝑥𝛾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma}, previously considered in short-range models in [4, 5, 15, 6]. We proved the phase transition for any α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1) when γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α∗}𝛾1𝛼1superscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\}, combining our estimates with a recent approach proposed in [29]. As mentioned in the introduction, if we allow for the nearest-neighbour term to be large we can obtain a larger parameter range for γ𝛾\gamma, namely γ>max⁡{1−α,1−α+}𝛾1𝛼1subscript𝛼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha_{+}\} where α∗<α+superscript𝛼subscript𝛼\alpha^{*}<\alpha_{+}. The entropy bound of [10] can be applied to contour weights w​(Γ)𝑤Γw(\Gamma) involving the exponential of the “contour norm” ‖Γ‖αsubscriptnormΓ𝛼||\Gamma||_{\alpha}. The reason why we cannot obtain a phase transition for γ>1−α𝛾1𝛼\gamma>1-\alpha for all α∈[0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1) is that when we add a field, we cannot lower-bound the contour energy by a constant times some appropriate α𝛼\alpha-contour norm for α≥α∗𝛼superscript𝛼\alpha\geq\alpha^{*}. One would need another entropy bound in order to tackle this problem. This is one possibility for further research.

The critical case seems to be similar to the standard Ising model with decaying fields, see [4]. In fact, for any 0≤α<10𝛼10\leq\alpha<1 we proved the phase transition when 1−α∗<1−α=γ1superscript𝛼1𝛼𝛾1-\alpha^{*}<1-\alpha=\gamma. For the case when h∗subscriptℎh_{*} is large and the model has a nearest-neighbour ferromagnetic interaction on ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d}, d≥2𝑑2d\geq 2, this question is still an open problem and there is some hope to see phase uniqueness for large values of h∗subscriptℎh_{*}. The situation is completely different from the Ising model on regular non-amenable trees where there is no possibility of phase transition in the critical case for models with decaying fields, see [6].

We conjecture, as indicated in the Introduction, that there is phase uniqueness at low temperature when γ<1−α𝛾1𝛼\gamma<1-\alpha, but we don’t have a rigorous proof so far.

In the short-range Ising model in higher dimensions, uniqueness has been proven. In [4] the uniqueness for low temperatures was proven, adapting an argument from [9], afterwards the phase uniqueness for all temperatures was obtained combining this with a result from [15] using random cluster representations for models with fields. A direct argument proving the phase uniqueness for all β>0𝛽0\beta>0 for Ising models with external fields decaying slowly is still unknown. We remark, by the way, that Potts models in a homogeneous field provide an example where there is both low-temperature uniqueness and high-temperature uniqueness, with a phase transition at some intermediate temperature, thus we will need to make use of some specific Ising properties.
